Award.AwardTitle: Heterogeneity in the phloem of minor veins
Award.AbstractNarration: The phloem transports nutrients, developmental signals and defense compounds throughout the plant body. It is often assumed that the phloem is a homogeneous tissue. However, on the basis of preliminary data the investigators suggest that, in the small veins of leaves where transported materials are loaded into the phloem, the network is heterogeneous in its structure and biochemistry, with specific functions assigned to distinct subsets of phloem cells. This hypothesis will be tested in several species by a number of techniques. Both light and electron microscopy will be used to quantify cell-specific features involved in transport, including the channels (plasmodesmata) that connect the phloem to surrounding cells. Cell-specific promoters (the DNA elements that control gene expression) will be used to identify cell types within veins and this information will be used in conjunction with microscopy to profile gene expression patterns in the different cell types. In a third project, specific phloem cells will be selectively killed with a toxin synthesized under the control of cell-specific promoters and these plants will be used to obtain and characterize phloem sap to identify nutrients, macromolecules and defense compounds transported in individual cell types. In terms of broader impacts, specific cells involved in the synthesis and transport of compounds required for the proper development and health of crop plants will be identified. Educational broader impacts include the incorporation of experimental hypotheses and results in undergraduate course material, employment of undergraduate students in phloem sap studies, and continued participation in the Cornell Prison Education Program. RNA sequence data will be deposited at the National Center for Biotechnology Information and processed data files will be uploaded to iPlant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The phloem is generally considered to consist of a uniform cluster of linked, elongated cells that transport sugars, other metabolites and developmental signals throughout the plant. In this grant period we explored the concept that the phloem is, in fact, heterogeneous, with specialized functions in specific cells. Our major finding was that the flowering regulator, Flowering Locus T (FT), which was thought to be synthesized in all phloem cells of leaves is produced in two specific longitudinal files of companion cells in the small (minor) vein network. This was shown to be the case in the herbaceous model plants, Arabidopsis thaliana and tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum). Since these are widely unrelated species it is reasonable to assume that this phenomenon of localized synthesis of the flowering signal is widespread, and perhaps ubiquitous, in dicotyledonous (broadleaved) plants. The same cells that synthesize FT also produce specialized transport sugars, raffinose and stachyose, in cucumber plants, indicating that the regulatory pathway leading to FT production is used in specific plant groups for additional purposes. Further analysis indicated that most of the numerous protein regulators of FT synthesis are produced in other cells in the veins, indicating that regulation of flowering, one of the most complex developmental systems in plants, involves intercellular transport of developmental signals from neighboring cells into the FT-producing cells, a previously unrecognized phenomenon. This opens up a new field in plant developmental biology.

 

In other studies, we analyzed the functional heterogeneity of the internal versus the external phloem of cucumber fruit and stems by a combination of microscopy, fluorescent dye displacement, micro-computed tomography, laser capture microdissection and RNA sequencing. These studies demonstrated a bias toward the transport of different metabolites and reproductive signals in one or the other phloem types. Additional studies in collaboration with biophysicists provided novel insights into polymer trapping, the unusual mechanism of loading photosynthetically-derived sugars into specialized phloem cells in the heterogeneous minor veins of cucumber, other cucurbits and several other families of flowering plants. With groups in China and Denmark we studied the effect of needle length on conifer phloem transport. During this grant period we also wrote reviews, in collaboration with other authors, on export of sugars from leaves, mechanisms of phloem loading, ecological aspects of phloem physiology and the phloem biology of the cucurbits.
